George Masterman (n. d.)
data.bio: [George Masterman was a man living in the Stonegrave area in 1663. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Frances Maude (died 1690)
data.bio: [Frances Maude was the daughter of Christopher Wandesford, 1st Baronet of Kirklington and his wife Eleanor; Alice Thornton's niece. She married Robert Maude of West Riddleston and Ripon, and they had a son and two daughters. She died on 5 January 1690.]

data.title: Lady Arabella McCarthy (1630-1697?)
data.bio: Lady Arabella McCarthy was born in October 1630 in London, the daughter of Thomas Wentworth and his second wife, Arabella. She was a childhood friend of Alice Thornton's in Dublin. She married Justin MacCarthy, 1st Viscount Mountcashel, about 13 years her junior. She was still alive (but ill) on 14 April 1697, when mentioned in a letter by Alice Thornton to Abstrupus Danby, and died without issue.

data.title: Sir Robert Meredith (c.1597-1668)
data.bio: [Robert Meredith was the son of Richard and Sarah Meredith, born c.1597. His father was Bishop of Leighlin. He married Anne Usher and they had three sons. He served as Chancellor of the Exchequer of Ireland from 1634 until his death. He held a Greenhills estate in Kildare. He died on 17 October 1668 and was buried in the family vault at St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin.]

data.title: Sander Metcalfe (n. d.)
data.bio: [Sander (Alexander?) Metcalfe lived in the Yorkshire Dales in 1644. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: William Metcalfe (n. d.)
data.bio: [William Metcalfe was a solicitor, in the employ of William Wandesford, Alice Thornton's uncle. Metcalfe acted as William Thornton's agent in Ireland in the 1650s, tasked with locating Christopher Wandesford's lost will.]

data.title: Anne Osborne (died 1666)
data.bio: [Anne Osborne was the daughter of Thomas Walmesley of Dunkenhalgh and his first wife, Eleanor. She married William Middleton and they had no children. On his death, she married (before 1630) Edward Osborne, Alice Thornton's maternal uncle, and became his second wife. They had a son. She was buried on 20 August 1666 at Harthill.]

data.title: Anne (Nan) Milbank (n. d.)
data.bio: [Anne Milbank, also known as Nan, was a servant in Alice Thornton's household in the late 1660s. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: Margery Millbanke (n. d.)
data.bio: [Margery Millbanke was a servant in the Thornton's household in 1667. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: William Mitchell (n. d.)
data.bio: [William Mitchell made two deeds with John Hall in April 1664. No further information on this man.]

data.title: George Monck (1608-1670)
data.bio: [George Monck, born 6 December 1608 at Great Potheridge, Devon, was the fourth son of Sir Thomas Monck, a landowner in Devon, and his wife, Elizabeth. He volunteered in the English expedition against Cadiz in 1625, which was the beginning of a very successful military career. A colonel in the Royalist army, he landed in Dublin in 1642 to quell the Irish uprising. He married Anne Clarges in 1653 and they had one son. He died on 1 January 1670.]

data.title: Mr Morrett (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Morrett was a neighbour of Alice Thornton's when she lived at East Newton Hall. He acted as an appraiser of William Thornton's goods after his death in 1668. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Philip Nesbit (died 1663)
data.bio: [Philip Nesbit was the son of Philip and Elizabeth Nesbit of York. He received his BA and MA from Corpus Christi, Cambridge in 1638 and 1641, and held the rectorship of Kirklington from 1649-62. He married Susan Hemmingway and they had six children, four sons and two daughters, five of whom survived childhood. He was removed from the rectorship of Kirklington in 1662 for refusing to subscribe to the Act of Uniformity. He died the next year and was buried at St Martins, York on 15 October 1663.]

data.title: Robert Nettleton (n. d.)
data.bio: [Robert Nettleton was a creditor of Christopher Wandesford, Alice Thornton's father. His dispute with Wandesford's heirs had been ongoing since at least 1652 with a case against Christopher Wandesford, Thornton's brother, over a debt of their father's which Nettleton took over from Lady Osbaldeston via her husband who had lent Wandesford £500. In 1653 and later in 1656 Nettleton was in dispute with Thornton's uncle William Wandesford. William Thornton inherited this debt when he took over the role of administering Wandesford's will from Maulger Norton from at least 1661, when Nettleton sent bailiffs to the Thornton residence. Possibly Robert Nettleton of Thornhill Lees who died in 1673.]

data.title: Elizabeth Nicholson (n.d.)
data.bio: [placeholder]

data.title: Mrs Norton (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mrs Norton may have been a relation of Alice Thornton's via her aunt and uncle Anne and Maulger Norton. She was alive in the late 1660s.]

data.title: Anne Norton (1593-1683)
data.bio: Anne Norton was the daughter of Sir George Wandesford and his wife, Catherine, born in 1593; she was Alice Thornton’s aunt. She married Maulger Norton on 4 March 1622. They had six children: four sons and two daughters. She was buried on 23 December 1683 at St Mary’s, Richmond.

data.title: Anthony Norton (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Anthony Norton was a relative of Alice Thornton, who was in the Ryedale area in the late 1660s. Possibly a relation of Maulger and Anne Norton of St Nicholas Richmond, Thornton's maternal aunt and uncle and perhaps the same Anthony Norton mentioned in Alice Wandesford's will of 1659 as 'my cousin'.]

data.title: Christopher Norton (died 1685?)
data.bio: [Christopher Norton was the third son of Maulger and Alice Thornton's maternal aunt Anne Norton; Alice Thornton's first cousin. He was still alive in 1685 when he sold the family home of St Nicholas, Richmond. He had a daughter, Anne.]

data.title: Edmund Norton (1622-1648)
data.bio: Edmund Norton was the second son of Maulger and Anne Norton, born in 1622. He attended Cambridge University and was admitted to Gray's Inn to study law in February 1646. He served as a colonel of Dragoons under John Mallory in the Skipton garrison in the 1640s. He married Jane Dudley of Chopwell on 10 February 1647 but it was a short marriage. He died in 1648 and was buried at St-Michael-le-Belfrey’s, York on 29 November.

data.title: Jane Clavering (died 1690)
data.bio: Jane Clavering, birth date unknown, was the daughter and sole heir of Toby and Jane Dudley of Chopwell. She married Edmund Norton on 10 February 1647 but he died in 1648. She then married Robert Clavering at St Ebba’s, Ebchester on 15 July 1651. They had four children (two sons and two daughters). She died in 1690.

data.title: John Norton (c.1637-1646)
data.bio: John Norton was the fourth son of Maulger and Anne Norton. Born c.1637, he died at the family home in Richmond of a consumption in 1646, aged nine.

data.title: Julian Norton (1633-1649)
data.bio: Julian Norton was the daughter of Maulger and Anne Norton, born 6 January 1633. She died aged 17 on 9 April 1649 at her father's house in Richmond, Yorkshire and was buried the next day at St Mary's, Richmond.

data.title: Maulger Norton (1594-1673)
data.bio: Maulger Norton was baptised on 25 March 1593 at All Saints’, Wath, the first son of Robert and Catherine Norton of St Nicholas, Richmond. He was elected MP for Richmond in the Short Parliament of 1640. He married Alice Thornton's paternal aunt, Anne Wandesford, on 4 March 1622, by whom he had six children (four sons and two daughters). He was receiver for crown venues for Northumberland, Durham and Richmond in the 1660s but by 1667 was in financial trouble and was briefly imprisoned and later suspended from receiving rents in those regions. He was buried at St Mary’s, Richmond on 12 December 1673.

data.title: William Norton (1625-1666)
data.bio: William Norton, baptised on 2 July 1625 at All Saints’, Manfield, Richmondshire was the son of Maulger and Anne Norton; he was Alice Thornton's first cousin. He was admitted to Gray's Inn on 2 September 1649 and was murdered in a tavern brawl in London in December 1666.

data.title: Sir Phelim Roe O'Neill (c.1604-1653)
data.bio: [Sir Phelim Roe O'Neill was the eldest son of Sir Turlough Oge O'Neill of Kinnard and his wife, Catherine, born c.1604. He was raised as a royal ward after his father's death and he entered Lincoln's Inn in 1618. Returning to Ireland in 1628, he returned to Catholicism. He was knighted by Thomas Wentworth, Lord Deputy of Ireland, in 1639. In 1641 he was one of the conspirators in the Irish Rebellion. He married three times: first, a daughter of Lord Iveagh, who died in 1641; secondly to Louise Preston. His third marriage was to Jean Gordon with whom he had a son. After a military defeat in 1653 he was captured and executed on 10 March.]

data.title: John Ogle (n. d.)
data.bio: [John Ogle was implicated in the murder of Alice Thornton's nephew, Thomas Danby, in London in 1667 but was pardoned and released from jail in October 1667.]

data.title: Sir Edward Osborne (1596-1647)
data.bio: Sir Edward Osborne, 1st Baronet Kiveton, son of Sir Hewett and Joyce Osborne, was baptised on 12 December 1596. He was the maternal uncle of Alice Thornton. Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge, he was admitted to the Inner Temple to study law in 1620. He was knighted and created Baronet by James I that same year and was vice president of the Council of the North. He married twice: on 13 October 1618 to Margaret Belasyse, with whom he had a son; after her death in 1624, to Anne Walmesley, widow of William Middleton, with whom he had another son. He died on 9 September 1647 at his family home of Kiveton Hall, South Yorkshire.

data.title: Sir Hewett Osborne (1567-1599)
data.bio: [Sir Hewett Osborne was baptised on 13 March 1567, the son of Sir Edward and Anna Osborne; he was Alice Thornton's maternal grandfather. A landowner and soldier, he married Joyce Fleetwood and they had a son and a daughter. He owned lands at Kiveton, Yorkshire, but lived in Essex. He died in September 1599.]

data.title: Lady Joyce Frescheville (1569-1619)
data.bio: [Joyce Frescheville, born 1569, was the daughter of Sir Thomas Fleetwood of the Vache and his second wife, Bridget; she was the maternal grandmother of Alice Thornton. She married Sir Hewett Osborne of Kiveton on 26 December 1588 and they had a son and a daughter. Widowed in 1599, she married Sir Peter Frescheville on 18 October 1604 and they had 3 children. She died on 16 April 1619 and was buried at St John the Baptist’s, Staveley, Derbyshire.]

data.title: Sir Thomas Osborne (1632-1712)
data.bio: [Sir Thomas Osborne, 1st Duke of Leeds was the second son of Sir Edward Osborne of Kiveton and his second wife, Anne, born on 20 February 1632; Alice Thornton’s first cousin. He became his father's heir in 1638 when his older brother was killed in an accident. His family property was sequestered after the battle of Marston Moor in 1644 and Osborne was exiled to Europe in the early 1650s. He married Bridget Bertie and they had 11 children (three sons and eight daughters). He became High Sheriff of Yorkshire in 1661 and Lord Treasurer 1673-79. In June 1674 he was made Earl of Danby. Impeached after the 'Popish Plot' in 1678, he spent the next six years in the Tower of London. He was then released on bail and played a key role in the plot against James II, advising William of Orange, who, on becoming king in 1688, made him President of the Privy Council. He was made Marquess of Carmarthen in April 1689. His cousin, Alice Thornton, wrote to him at least three times asking for his help: when he was Lord Treasurer in 1673 about a dispute between Osborne and her brother Christopher; in July 1689, thanking him with helping her son Robert to gain preferment; and in September 1689, seeking preferment for her son-in-law, Thomas Comber. He was made Duke of Leeds in May 1694, but the next year was involved in a corruption scandal and left the political arena. He died on 26 July 1712 at his daughter Sophia’s house in Easton Neston, Northamptonshire. He was buried at All Hallows’, Harthill.]

data.title: Mary Palmes (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mary Palmes was the daughter of William Eure, sixth Baron Eure of Malton. She married William Palmes, later MP for Malton, on 15 July 1663. They had four sons and four daughters.]

data.title: Barbara Pape (died 1675)
data.bio: [Barbara Pape, then Todd, worked as a maid for Anne Danby and lived in the Thornton household in the 1660s. She left their household in 1668, after being implicated in spreading rumours. She married John Pape on 29 May 1670 at Nunnington. They had at least one child. She was buried on 9 September 1675 at St Leonard's, New Malton.]

data.title: John Pape (born 1630?)
data.bio: [John Pape was possibly born 13 March 1630 at St Leonard’s, New Malton to William Pape. He married Barbara Todd, who had been a maid in the service of Anne Danby, on 29 May 1670 at All Saints’ and St James, Nunnington. They had at least one child.]

data.title: Christopher Parkes (born c.1642)
data.bio: Christopher Parkes, born c.1642, attended St John's College, Cambridge where he graduated with an MA in 1663. He was vicar of Catterick from 1660 and minister of the chapel at Hipswell, Bolton-super-Swale and Hudswell. We do not know when he died.

data.title: Sir William Parsons (c.1570-1650)
data.bio: [William Parsons was the son of James and Catherine Parsons, born c.1570. He became one of the Lord Justices of Ireland after the death of Alice Thornton's father, Christopher Wandesford, in 1640 until 1642. He had previously been Surveyor General of Ireland and an MP for County Wicklow. He married Elizabeth Lany and they had 12 children, five sons and seven daughters. He died in January or February 1650 and is buried at St Margaret’s, Westminster.]

data.title: Sir John Payton (1561-1616)
data.bio: [Sir John Payton was the son of Robert and Elizabeth Payton, born 1561. He married Alice Osborne, sister of Hewett Osborne, making him Alice Thornton's maternal great-uncle by marriage. John and Alice had six sons and seven daughters. He was twice elected MP for Cambridgeshire, in 1593 and in 1604, and died on 19 December 1616.]

data.title: Mary Plewes (born 1636?)
data.bio: [Mary Plewes lived in Yorkshire in the late 1660s. She was possibly the Mary Plewes, daughter of John Plewes, baptised at St Gregory’s, Bedale in 1636. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: John Plummer (n. d.)
data.bio: [John Plummer discovered the body of George Wandesford, Alice Thornton's brother, near Catterick Bridge on the river Swale in 1651. We have not been able to trace him further, although the name 'Plummer' is attested in Easby parish registers and wills from Richmond, Reeth and Bedale.]

data.title: Elizabeth (Bess) Poore (n. d.)
data.bio: [Elizabeth Poore, also known as Bess, was a servant in Alice Wandesford's house at Hipswell, probably in the 1650s when Thornton and her husband were living there. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: Frances Portington (died 1705)
data.bio: [Frances Portington was the daughter of Robert and Elizabeth Thornton and was the youngest sister of Alice Thornton's husband, William. She became the third wife of Timothy Portington of Malton on 27 July 1663 and they had one son. She was buried at St Michael’s, New Malton on 11 March 1705.]

data.title: Timothy Portington (c.1630-1697)
data.bio: [Timothy Portington was the son of Francis and Ellen Portington, born c.1630. An apothecary in New Malton, he was married three times; to Mary Pye (d.1654), Mary Ruddock (d.1662), and Frances Thornton; the younger sister of Alice Thornton's husband, William. He had a daughter with Mary Ruddock and a son with Frances. He died on 26 June 1697.]

Thomas Preston (1585-1655)
data.bio: [Thomas Preston was the second son of Christopher, 4th Viscount Gormanston, and his second wife, Catherine, born in 1585. Destined for a military career after attending the Irish college at Douai, he became a captain in the regiment of Henry O'Neill and served in the Netherlands. He married twice: first Clara van der Eycken of Flanders, with whom he had two sons, before her death in 1621; second, Marguerite of Namur with whom he probably had two more children, although these could have also been with his first wife. He frequently returned to Ireland in the 1640s and was appointed commander of the army of Leinster in 1642. He was made Viscount Tara and Governor of Waterford in 1650. He returned to Flanders and died there on 21 October 1655.]

data.title: Sir James Preston? (n. d.)
data.bio: [This is probably Sir James Preston (nicknamed Don Diego), second son of Thomas Preston, 1st Viscount Tara and his first wife Clara, who played a prominent military role in Ireland in the 1640s.]

data.title: Katherine Danby (1656-1726)
data.bio: Katherine Danby was the fourth child of Alice and William Thornton, and the second of the two that survived to adulthood. She was born on 12 June 1656 at Hipswell Hall and baptised the next day by Michael Syddall, probably at St Anne’s, Catterick. In the later 1660s she was sent with her sister Nally to study at York. She married Thomas Purchas, rector, by arrangement of her brother-in-law, Thomas Comber, on 27 December 1682. She had five children by Purchas (three sons and two daughters). After Purchas's death in April 1697, she married Robert Danby of Northallerton in 1698, without her mother’s approval. She died on 17 December 1726 and was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave.

data.title: Sir George Radcliffe (1593-1657)
data.bio: [Sir George Ratcliffe was the son of Nicholas and Margaret Ratcliffe, baptised on 21 April 1593. He was educated at University College Oxford where he graduated in May 1612, having entered Gray's Inn in February 1612. He was called to the bar in 1618. He was briefly engaged to the only daughter of John Finch but she died age 10 in 1621. He married Anne Trappes at Thornhill, York on 21 February 1622. This made him a cousin-by-marriage of Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl Strafford, and George became part of Strafford's Irish administration 1633-40. He was imprisoned in Dublin Castle after being tried for treason in 1640. After his release in 1642 he spent much of his time in the Netherlands and died in 1657. George and Anne had a son.]

data.title: Mr Raines (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Raines was a man to whom William Thornton was in debt, as well as his brother-in-law Timothy Portington. He could be John Raynes of Appleton-le-Street, west of Malton, who held the manor of Malton Priory until 1665, or Thomas Raynes, an attorney and Lord Mayor of York in the 1660s.]

Martha Richison (n. d.)
data.bio: [Martha Richison was a witness at Alice and William Thornton's wedding in 1651. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: Jane Rimer (n. d.)
data.bio: [Jane Rimer was a midwife active in the Richmondshire area in the mid-1650s. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: Mr Robinson (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Robinson was possibly Thomas Robinson of Easby, who held land in the Richmond area.]

data.title: Anne Robinson (n. d.)
data.bio: [Anne Robinson was a maid in the Thornton household in the early 1660s. We have not been able to trace her further.]

data.title: Matthew Robinson (1628-1694)
data.bio: Matthew Robinson, the third son of Thomas and Frances Robinson, was baptised at St Mary the Virgin, Rokeby, North Yorks on 14 December 1628. He graduated from Cambridge in 1652 and was appointed vicar of St Lambert’s, Burneston in 1651, which he held for 40 years. He married Jane Pickering on 12 October 1657. They had no children. He died at Ripley on 27 November 1694 and was buried at St Lambert, Burneston.

data.title: Mr Roose (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Roose was a clergyman who came to Holy Trinity, Stonegrave with Gilbert Bennett in 1666 to help him administer the parish. We have not been able to identify him further.]

data.title: Prince Rupert (1619-1682)
data.bio: [Prince Rupert of the Palatinate, Duke of Cumberland was born on 18 December 1619 to Frederick V of the Palatinate and Countess Louisa Juliana of Nassau. One of the main military commanders in the Wars of the Three Kingdoms, he never married, but had two children, a son with Francesca Bard, to whom his marriage has never been acknowledged (although a purported marriage certificate dated 1664 has been found), and a daughter with Margaret Hughes. He died on 29 November 1682.]

data.title: Sir William Ryves (died 1648)
data.bio: [Sir William Ryves was the sixth son of John and Elizabeth Ryves of Blandford, Dorset. He entered Middle Temple in 1593 and was called to the bar in 1600. He became Attorney General of Ireland in November 1619, a position he held until 1636 when he resigned to become justice of the court of King's Bench. He was MP for Belturbet, county Cavan, in 1634-5. He was Speaker of the Irish House of Lords in 1641-2. He married twice, first to a woman called Latham or Jackman, with whom he had four sons and four daughters, and second to Dorothy Waldron. He died in Dublin in 1648.]

data.title: Dr Peter Samways (1615-1693)
data.bio: [Peter Samways was born in 1615 in Eltham, Kent. He attended Westminster School and then Trinity College, Cambridge, where he gained his MA in 1641. He was ordained Deacon of Rochester in 1643. A loyal monarchist, he was nevertheless presented to the rector of Wath, Yorks in 1658 on petition to Cromwell. With the Restoration in 1660, he was created Doctor of Divinity at Cambridge and then was made prebendary of Barneby, York in 1668. A friend of Thornton and correspondent with her son-in-law, Thomas Comber, he died on 6 April 1693 and was buried at St Gregory’s, Bedale.]

data.title: Anne Overton (1647-1679)
data.bio: [Anne Overton, the daughter of Robert and Mabel Wake, was baptised 19 January 1647. She married James Savile, 2nd Earl of Sussex, and they had a son, James, who did not survive infancy. After her husband’s death in 1671, she married Fairfax Overton in April 1674. She died in 1679.]

data.title: Laurence Sayer (born c.1632)
data.bio: [Laurence Sayer, son of Laurence and Elizabeth Sayer, was born c.1632. The Sayers were a recusant family in Worsall, Northallerton, whose estates had been forfeited in the 1650s when they were owned by Laurence Sayer senior. Laurence Sayer junior borrowed heavily to buy back the estates. He is possibly the same Laurence Sayer who married Catherine Burdon in 1690, who went on to have a son, Robert.]

data.title: B. Scarbrough (n.d.)
data.bio: [placeholder]

data.title: George Scott (c.1634-c.1700)
data.bio: [This is probably George Scott, son of George Scott, rector of St Wilfrid’s, Langton-on-Swale, born c.1634. He attended Giggleswick School and was admitted to Christ's College, Cambridge in 1649, obtaining his BA in 1652 and MA in 1663. He was instituted to the rectory of St Oswald, King and Martyr, Oswaldkirk in 1663, a position he held until his death c.1700. He was also possibly the rector of St John Baptist, Kirkby Wiske, from 1661-92. He had at least one son and two or more daughters.]

Gilbert Sheldon (1598-1677)
data.bio: [Gilbert Sheldon was the youngest son of Roger Sheldon, born 19 June 1598. His father was bailiff to Gilbert Talbot, the earl of Shrewsbury. He graduated from Trinity College, Oxford, in 1617, and got his MA from Cambridge in 1620. After entering All Souls as a fellow, he was ordained deacon by the Bishop of Oxford at Dorchester and probably ordained priest shortly afterwards. A royalist during the war, he was made Archbishop of Canterbury in 1663, a position he held until his death on 9 November 1677.]

data.title: Grace(?) Sherwood (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mrs Sherwood was the wife of Elias Sherwood of Petergate, York, who owned lodgings in the late 1660s. A surviving indenture for the property on Petergate shows it was leased by one James Sherwood in 1662. She is perhaps Grace (née Bond) of Breighton who married one Elias Sherwood at All Saints’, Bubwith, East Yorkshire, on 2 November 1665.]

data.title: Richard Shuttleworth (1587-1669)
data.bio: [Richard Shuttleworth was the son of Thomas and Anne Shuttleworth, born 1587. In 1607 he inherited the newly-built Gawthorpe Hall from his uncle, Lawrence Shuttleworth. He married Fleetwood Barton with whom he had 12 children (eight sons and four daughters). A parliamentarian, he was a colonel during the Wars of the Three Kingdoms, and MP for Preston from 1640-48. He was re-elected in 1654 during the Interregnum, when he also leading magistrate for Blackburn hundred. He died in 1669.]

data.title: Enoch(?) Sinclair (n. d.)
data.bio: [Possibly Enoch Sinclair, rector of Slingsby, who was educated at St John's College Cambridge, graduating in 1633 and made curate of Auburn Chapel, Carnaby, East Riding in 1635, a position he held until at least 1638.]

data.title: William Skinner (c.1627-1680)
data.bio: [This is probably William Skinner, born c.1627, merchant, alderman of Hull and mayor in 1664. He married Jane Foxley, daughter of William Foxley, but she died in 1652. He built a house on the east side of the High Street in 1672, which had 13 hearths; it was later known as Etherington House and was demolished after being damaged in World War Two. He died on 19 September 1680.]

Dr Smith (n. d.)
data.bio: Dr Smith was a physician active in the Richmondshire area in the late 1650s. We have not been able to trace him further.

data.title: Dr Henry Smith (c.1560-1591)
data.bio: Henry Smith was born c.1560 in Withcote, Leicestershire, to Erasmus and Anne Smith. He was admitted to Queen’s College, Cambridge in 1573, leaving soon afterwards to attend Lincoln College, Oxford, graduating with his BA in 1579. He became a lecturer at St Clement Danes without Temple Bar in 1587. Suffering with poor health, he died on 4 July 1591 and was buried at Husbands Bosworth. While he has been described as the most popular Puritan preacher of the Elizabethan era, Smith had little time for separatist ideas and his avoidance of controversial theological issues made his sermons very popular. Over twenty editions of his collected sermons were published between 1592 and 1675.

data.title: Lady Mary Smith (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mary Smith was the daughter of Hugh and Elizabeth Smith of Long Ashton, Somerset. She married Sir Thomas Smith of Hatherton, Cheshire. They had 22 children. We do not know when she died.]

data.title: Mr Smith (n.d.)
data.bio: [placeholder]

data.title: Sir Thomas Smith (c.1595-c.1668)
data.bio: [Sir Thomas Smith was the son of Thomas and Anne Smith of Hatherton, Cheshire, born c.1595. Mayor of Chester from 1622 and High Sheriff of Cheshire in 1623, he sat as MP for Chester 1640-44 in the Short and then Long Parliaments before being barred from Parliament for his royalist support. He married Mary Smith and they had 22 children. He died c.1668.]

data.title: [Unknown] Smithson (n. d.)
data.bio: [Uncle Smithson is one of Sir Jerome's Smithson's paternal uncles, Francis, Richard or John. We are not able to identify him any more precisely.]

data.title: Mr Smithson (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Smithson owned a shop in Richmond in 1660. He has not been traced further.]

data.title: Sir Hugh Smithson (c.1598-1670)
data.bio: [Sir Hugh Smithson of Stanwick St John, North Yorkshire, was the son of Anthony and Eleanor Smithson, born c.1598. He was a London merchant, recusant and royalist, made Baronet of Stanwick in 1660 by Charles II for his support. He married Dorothy Rawsthorne and they had four sons and two daughters. He died on 21 October 1670.]

data.title: Sir Jerome Smithson (1632-1684)
data.bio: [Sir Jeremy (later Jerome) Smithson, 2nd Baronet Stanwick, was the eldest son and heir of Sir Hugh Smithson, 1st Baronet Stanwick, and his wife, Dorothy, born 1632. In the late 1640s or very early 1650s he plotted to abduct Alice Thornton, but a man named Thomas Binks, possibly a friend or associate of his, warned her of the plot and she was able to escape. He married Mary Wingate, and they had a son and a daughter. A deposition against Smithson for libel taken at York Castle in 1665 provides clear evidence that he changed his name from Jeremy to Jerome. He became 2nd Baronet Stanwick on his father's death in 1670 and died in 1684.]

data.title: Thomas Sober (n.d.)
data.bio: [placeholder]

data.title: [Unknown] Stone (n. d.)
data.bio: [This is Anne, Beatrice, Margery or another unnamed daughter of Christopher Stone, Chancellor of York, and his wife Grace. We are unable to be any more precise about the identification.]

data.title: Dr Christopher Stone (died 1686)
data.bio: [This is probably Dr Christopher Stone, ordained deacon in 1635 and priest in 1637 by Thomas Morton, bishop of Durham. He was instituted rector of St Peter’s, Dalby in 1640 and Chancellor of York in 1662. He was rector of St Leonard, Beeford, 1669-85. He married Grace Robinson and had at least four children, three daughters and a son. He was buried at York Minster on 26 November 1686.]

data.title: George Straherne (n. d.)
data.bio: [George Straherne was a friend or employee of Christopher Wandesford in Dublin in 1640. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Charles Stuart (1600-1649)
data.bio: [Charles I of England, born 19 November 1600 to James I and VI and Anne of Denmark, was king of England, Scotland and Ireland from 1625 and the reigning monarch for the first 23 years of Alice Thornton's life. He married Henrietta Maria and had nine children (four sons and five daughters). He was executed on 30 January 1649.]

data.title: Charles Stuart (1630-1685)
data.bio: [Charles Stuart, King Charles II of England, Scotland and Ireland, was born on 29 May 1630 to King Charles I and Henrietta Maria. He was King of Scotland 1649-51 and King of England, Scotland and Ireland from the Restoration of 1660 until his death in 1685. He married Catherine of Braganza but had no legitimate issue. He fathered at least twelve children out of wedlock by various mistresses. He died on 6 February 1685.]

data.title: Dame Sworre (n. d.)
data.bio: [Dame Sworre, possibly a midwife, was active in the Yorkshire area in the 1640s. Her title indicates that she was perhaps widowed. We have not been able to identify her further.]

data.title: Michael Syddall (1614-1659)
data.bio: Michael Syddall was baptised on 30 September 1614 at SS Martin and Gregory’s, York, the son of William Syddall, a baker, and his wife, Margaret. He was admitted to Christ's College, Cambridge in 1631 at the age of 16, graduating with his B.A. in 1635 and M.A. in 1638. He married Ellen Hunton, widow of the steward of the late Christopher Wandesford. He was minister at St Michael the Archangel’s, Kirklington, 1644-9 and vicar of St Anne’s, Catterick, from 1645-58. He was buried on 8 January 1658 in the chancel at St Anne’s. In his will, dated 3 January 1658, he left money to build a school and he made William Thornton one of four trustees.

data.title: Charles Tancred (c.1631-1711)
data.bio: [Charles Tancred of Arden Hall was born c.1631, the son of William Tancred of Arden. He married Barbara Dalton, and they had 18 children, 12 sons and six daughters, of which only three survived to adulthood. In 1660 he was charged with threatening the peace of the Commonwealth, and in 1668 he was one of the people spreading rumours about Thornton and Comber. He died aged 80, on 26 February 1711 and was buried at All Saints’, Hawnby in the same grave as his wife.]

data.title: Thomas Thompson (n. d.)
data.bio: [Thomas Thompson was in the Ryedale area in 1668. We have not been able to identify him further.]

data.title: Mr Thomson (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Thomson was a man living at Catterick Bridge in the early 1650s. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Unnamed Thornton (1652-1652)
data.bio: Alice Thornton's first child, an unnamed daughter, was born on 27 August 1652 but lived for less than an hour and so was not baptised. She was buried at St Agatha’s, Easby the next day.

data.title: Unnamed Thornton (1657-1657)
data.bio: An unnamed Thornton son born on 10 December 1657; the fifth child of Alice and William Thornton. He lived only half an hour after a difficult birth. He was buried at St Anne’s Church, Catterick the same day by Michael Syddall.

data.title: Alice Thornton (1626-1707)
data.bio: Alice Thornton was born to Christopher and Alice Wandesford in Kirklington, North Yorkshire on 13 February 1626, and baptised at St Michael’s on 19 February. She was their fifth child of seven and the youngest daughter. She married William Thornton on 15 December 1651 and they had nine children, three of whom survived to adulthood. A widow from the age of 44, she died at East Newton and was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave on 1 February 1707.

data.title: Christopher Thornton (1667-1667)
data.bio: [Christopher Thornton was the 9th child of Alice and William Thornton. He was born at East Newton, 11 November 1667 and baptized the next day at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. He contracted smallpox and died on 1 December 1667. He was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave the following day.]

data.title: Dorothy Thornton (n.d.)
data.bio: [placeholder]

data.title: Elizabeth (Betty) Thornton (1655-1656)
data.bio: Elizabeth (nicknamed Betty) Thornton was born on 14 February 1655 to Alice and William Thornton and baptised on 16 February at St Anne’s, Catterick. She was their third child. She died on 3 September 1656, aged 18 months, and was buried at St Anne’s, Catterick.

data.title: Elizabeth Gates (1597-1655)
data.bio: Elizabeth Gates, born 3 October 1597 at Buttercrambe, was the eldest daughter of Sir Richard Darley of Buttercrambe and his second wife, Elizabeth (née Gates). She became the second wife of Robert Thornton on 6 June 1618 and they had seven children (four sons and three daughters). After his death in 1637, she married Geoffrey Gates on 26 June 1638 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. Her joint-eldest son, William, married Alice Thornton in 1651. She died on 10 May 1655 at Oswaldkirk and was buried the next day at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave.

data.title: John Thornton (1633-1669)
data.bio: [John Thornton was the son of Robert and Elizabeth Thornton of East Newton; William Thornton's younger brother. He was born on 5 October 1633 and baptised on 10 October at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. He died on 22 May 1669 and was buried at Holy Trinity the next day.]

data.title: Joyce Thornton (1665-1666)
data.bio: [Joyce Thornton was the 8th child of Alice and William Thornton, born on 23 September 1665 at East Newton and baptized on 28 September at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. She fell ill on 20 January 1666 and died on 26 January. She was buried the next day at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave.]

data.title: Richard Thornton (1624-1656)
data.bio: Richard Thornton, born on 2 June 1624 and baptised on 9 June, was the son of Robert Thornton and his second wife, Elizabeth, and the twin brother of William Thornton. He died unmarried in Dublin on 3 July 1656 and was buried at St Patrick's Cathedral the next day.

data.title: Robert Thornton (c.1575-1637)
data.bio: [Robert Thornton was the son of William and Eleanor Thornton of East Newton, born c.1575; he was William Thornton’s father. His first marriage was to Dorothy Metham and they had four daughters, one of whom died in infancy. He then married Elizabeth Darley, with whom he had seven children, four sons and three daughters. He was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave on 27 May 1637.]

data.title: Robert Thornton (1662-1692)
data.bio: [Robert Thornton was the seventh child and third son of Alice and William Thornton. He was born on 19 September 1662 at East Newton and baptised the next day at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. He was educated first by his uncle, John Denton, then by the reverend John Burton at Sutton-on-the-Forest. He entered Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge in April 1680, before moving to University College, Oxford in May 1682. In 1687 he became the rector of Oddington, Gloucestershire but resigned it later that year. By 1688 he was in considerable debt and in 1689 he was working as a cleric on a naval ship. In 1691 he was offered a living in Northamptonshire but swapped it for that of Boldon, diocese of Durham, and resided at the Deanery in Durham with his sister, Alice, and her husband, Thomas Comber. In 1692 Comber helped arrange a marriage for him, to a woman worth £2800, but he fell ill and died on 4 June 1692, aged 29, and was buried in the Chapel of the Nine Altars, Durham Cathedral.]

data.title: Thomas Thornton (1626-1685)
data.bio: [Thomas Thornton was the son of Robert and Elizabeth Thornton, and the younger brother of William Thornton, baptised 29 August 1626 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. He was buried on 17 August 1685 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave.]

data.title: William Thornton (1624-1668)
data.bio: William Thornton, the son of Robert Thornton of East Newton and his second wife, Elizabeth, was born (along with his twin brother, Richard) on 2 June 1624 and baptized at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave on 9 June. He married Alice Wandesford on 15 December 1651 at Hipswell Hall. They had nine children, of whom three outlived him. He performed the role of Justice of the Peace sometime around the early 1660s. He died at Malton on 17 September 1668 and was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave the next day. His wife commissioned a plaque in his memory, which is still there today.

data.title: William Thornton (1660-1660)
data.bio: William Thornton, the 6th child and 2nd son of Alice and William Thornton, was born and baptized at her aunt Anne Norton’s house, St Nicholas, Richmond, on 17 April 1660. He died on 28 April 1660 of smallpox and was buried the next day at St Agatha’s, Easby, in the same grave as Thornton’s first child, an unnamed girl.

data.title: Francis Thorpe (1594-1665)
data.bio: [Francis Thorpe was the eldest son of Roger and Elizabeth Thorpe of Birdsall, Yorkshire, born in 1594. He was admitted to Gray's Inn in 1611 and graduated from St John's College, Cambridge in 1614. He was called to the bar in 1621. He was elected Recorder of Beverley in 1624. He married the twice-widowed Elizabeth Denton (née Oglethorpe). In 1645 he was elected 'recruiter' MP (filling a vacancy caused by a by-election) for Richmond. During the second English Civil War he played an important role organising Parliamentary forces in the North and was appointed serjeant-at-law in 1648. While named commissioner to try the king in January 1649 he took no part in it. Later in 1649 he was appointed to ride the northern circuit. On 1 June that year he was made one of the Barons of the Exchequer. He was elected MP for Beverley in 1654 but was prevented from sitting due to refusing to try fellow Yorkshiremen after Penruddock's rising. He took up his seat in 1659 and was reinstated as Baron of the Exchequer in 1660. He was buried at All Hallows’, Bardsey on 7 June 1665.]

data.title: Mr Tirrill (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Tirrill of Hoddesdon was a chief mourner at the funeral of Alice Thornton's brother John Wandesford at St Augustine’s, Broxbourne, Hertfordshire in 1664. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Mrs Tirrill (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mrs Tirrill was the wife of Mr Tirrill of Hoddesdon, Hertfordshire, alive in 1664 when they attended the funeral of John Wandesford in Broxbourne. We have not been able to identify her further.]

data.title: Sarah Tomlinson (n. d.)
data.bio: Sarah Tomlinson was a servant in the Wandesford household. She was a nursemaid at Kirklington in the late 1620s and moved with the family to London in the early 1630s. We have not been able to trace her further.

data.title: Mr Troutbeck (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Troutbeck lived in the Richmondshire area in the mid-1650s and was an acquaintance of Alice Wandesford, Thornton’s mother. We have not been able to trace him further.]

data.title: Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1603)
data.bio: [Elizabeth I was Queen of England from 1558 until her death in 1603. Born on 7 September 1533, she was the daughter of Henry VIII and his second wife, Anne Boleyn. She died on 24 March 1603.]

data.title: Mr Tully (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mr Tully was a man living in or near Stonegrave in 1663. He was possibly George Tully, who resigned as prebend of Ripon in 1681; or Timothy Tully (1613-99), Canon of York from 1660.]

data.title: Katherine Cholmley (c.1607-1672)
data.bio: [Katherine Cholmley was the daughter of the Stapletons of Wighill; mother Mary and father Robert or Henry, born c.1607. She married George Twisleton (died c.1635), and then married Henry Cholmley, MP for New Malton 1641-48. They had three children, two sons and a daughter. She was buried on 14 June 1672 at St Oswald, King and Martyr, Oswaldkirk.]

data.title: Ralph Wallis (n.d.)
data.bio: [placeholder]

data.title: Alice Wandesford (1593-1659)
data.bio: Alice Wandesford, the daughter of Hewett and Joyce Osborne of Kiveton, was born in Isleham, Cambs and baptised on 16 January 1593. She married Christopher Wandesford in 1614 and they had seven children, with five surviving past childhood, including Alice Thornton. She and her children joined her husband in Dublin c.1634 but she was widowed suddenly in December 1640. They fled back to northern England after the Irish rebellion of 1641, living from 1644 at her jointure property, Hipswell Hall. She died on 10 December 1659 and was buried at St Anne’s, Catterick.

data.title: Sir Christopher Wandesford (c.1548-1590)
data.bio: [Sir Christopher Wandesford was the son of Francis and Jane Wandesford of Kirklington born c.1548; he was Alice Thornton's great-grandfather. He married Elizabeth Bowes c.1568 and they had four children (three sons and a daughter). He was the Vice President of the Council of the North and was responsible for escorting Mary Queen of Scots from Carlisle to Bolton in 1568. He was buried at St Michael the Archangel’s, Kirklington on 11 July 1590.]

data.title: Christopher Wandesford (1592-1640)
data.bio: Christopher Wandesford was the eldest son and heir of Sir George Wandesford and his wife, Catherine. He was born at Bishop Burton, East Riding on 24 September 1592. He attended Clare College, Cambridge but returned home on his father's death to provide for his siblings. He married Alice Osborne in 1614 and they had seven children, five of whom survived childhood, including Alice Thornton. He was an MP in Yorkshire in the 1620s. In 1633 he relocated the family to Dublin, Ireland, to serve as Master of Rolls and became MP for County Kildare. In 1640 he was briefly Lord Deputy of Ireland before he died on 3 December 1640. He was buried at Christ Church, Dublin, on 10 December 1640.

data.title: Christopher Wandesford (1617-1627)
data.bio: [Christopher Wandesford was the son of Christopher and Alice Wandesford, born in 16167. He was Alice Thornton's brother. He died age 10 in 1627.]

data.title: Sir Christopher Wandesford (1628-1687)
data.bio: Sir Christopher Wandesford was born on 2 February 1628, the son of Christopher and Alice Wandesford; he was Alice Thornton's younger brother. He was baptised at St Michael the Archangel’s, Kirklington on 14 February 1628. He became heir on his brother George’s death in March 1651 and married Eleanor Lowther, who had been intended for his brother, on 30 September 1651. He was made 1st Baronet of Kirklington in 1660 and was elected MP for Ripon in 1679 and again in 1680. He had 12 children. He died in London on 23 February 1687 and was buried on 12 March at St Michael the Archangel’s, Kirklington.

data.title: Eleanor Wandesford (1633-1714)
data.bio: Eleanor Lowther, the daughter of Sir John Lowther and his first wife Mary, was baptised on 23 March 1633 at St Michael’s, Lowther. She was betrothed to George Wandesford but after his drowning married his younger brother, Sir Christopher Wandesford, on 30 September 1651 at Lowther. Her marriage portion from her father amounted to £2,000. They had nine children (three sons and six daughters). She was buried on 20 December 1714 at St Michael the Archangel’s, Kirklington.

data.title: Sir George Wandesford (1572-1612)
data.bio: [Sir George Wandesford was the son of Sir Christopher and Elizabeth Wandesford; born 20 May 1572; he was the father of Christopher Wandesford and Alice Thornton’s paternal grandfather. He married twice: first Catherine Hansby, on 10 August 1591, with whom he had three sons and a daughter, and after her death, Mary Pamplyn, with whom he had a son and a daughter. He was knighted at Whitehall in 1607. He seems to have been imprudent and extravagant with regards to finances, and much of his inheritance was lost or sold during his lifetime. He died on a trip to London on 11 September 1612 and was buried at St Andrew’s, Holborn, London.]

data.title: George Wandesford (1623-1651)
data.bio: George Wandesford, born 14 September 1623, was Christopher and Alice Wandesford's eldest son; his godfather was Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford. He attended Trinity College, Dublin from 1636, when the family were living in Ireland. Accused of taking part in the battle of Marston Moor in July 1644, his estates were sequestered and he moved to Hipswell Hall, his mother's property, before fleeing to France for the remainder of the fighting in England. He drowned in the River Swale, through which he was riding on horseback, on 31 March 1651, and was buried at St Michael the Archangel’s, Kirklington.

data.title: John Wandesford (c.1632-1664)
data.bio: John Wandesford was the fourth son of Christopher and Alice Wandesford. He was probably born in London c.1632 and the family moved to Ireland about a year later. After returning to Yorkshire in the mid-1640s, he was educated at schools in Bedale, Chester and Richmond, before entering Christ's College, Cambridge (1649-51). He was elected MP for Richmond in 1661 and died in his lodgings at London on 2 December 1664. He was buried at St Augustine’s, Broxbourne, Hertfordshire.

data.title: Joyce Wandesford (1618-1620)
data.bio: [Joyce Wandesford was baptised at St Michael the Archangel’s, Kirklington, on 3 June 1618. She was the third child of Christopher and Alice Wandesford; Alice Thornton’s sister. She died aged two and was buried on 11 September 1620 at St Michael the Archangel’s, Kirklington.]

data.title: William Wandesford (n. d.)
data.bio: [William Wandesford of Pickhill was the son of Richard and Muriel Wandesford and was a distant cousin of Alice Thornton's father, Christopher Wandesford. He married Elizabeth Ayscough on 27 October 1619 and by 1624 they had three sons. He was in Dublin in 1640 and was a witness to Christopher Wandesford's will. He was later an executor of Wandesford's estate.]

data.title: William Wandesford (1605-1690)
data.bio: William Wandesford was the youngest son of Sir George Wandesford by his second wife, Mary; he was Alice Thornton's uncle. He was baptised on 26 August 1605 at St Michael the Archangel’s, Kirklington. His brother, Christopher Wandesford, sent him to be an apprentice to a London merchant. He married Rebecca Reade and they had a daughter, Catherine. He was granted an annuity of £20 for life on 30 June 1637 out of Wandesford property at Castlecomer, Ireland, paid yearly at Christ's Church, Dublin. He suffered severe losses during the Wars of the Three Kingdoms due to his loyalty to the royalist cause. According to Thornton, a committee who advised Charles I during his trial met in his London home. He was made a gentleman-pensioner by Charles II after the Restoration in 1660 and died in 1690.

Luke Wastell (n. d.)
data.bio: [Luke Wastell was the third son of Leonard and Anne Wastell of Scorton and Kirkby Knowle. He married twice; first Sarah Laton and then Elizabeth Allison (née Pattison). He was a Parliamentarian during the 1640s. He is possibly the Luke Wastell buried at St Mary’s, Kirkby Fleetham on 16 February 1697.]

data.title: Dr Henry Watkinson (1628-1712)
data.bio: [Dr Henry Watkinson was the son of Henry Watkinson. He was born in Ilkley and baptised on 24 April 1628 at St Peter’s, Leeds. He attended Ilkley School and matriculated at St John's College, Cambridge in 1645, getting his BA in 1649. He obtained his doctorate in law from Padua in 1659. He was Chancellor of York 1673-1712. He married Elizabeth Hodgson (née Jennings) and they had a son, Christopher. He died on 25 April 1712 and was buried at St Cuthbert’s, York.]

data.title: Lady Anne Watson (1627-1696)
data.bio: Lady Anne Watson was born on 8 October 1627 in Finningley, Nottinghamshire, the eldest daughter of Thomas Wentworth and his second wife, Arabella. She was a childhood friend of Alice Thornton's in Dublin. She married Edward Watson, 2nd Baron Rockingham, on 24 November 1654, and they had eight children (four sons and four daughters). She died on 2 January 1696 and was buried at St Leonard’s, Rockingham six days later, where a monument to commemorate her was erected by her son, George.

data.title: Mrs Wattson (n. d.)
data.bio: [Mrs Wattson was a midwife, friend or servant of Alice Thornton in the early 1660s. We have not been able to identify her further.]

data.title: Robert Webster (died 1667)
data.bio: [Robert Webster was an acquaintance of Alice and William Thornton who lived in Nunnington in the 1650s and 1660s. He was buried at All Saints and St James’s, Nunnington on 27 October 1667.]

data.title: Anne (Nan) Wellburne (n. d.)
data.bio: [Anne Wellburne, known as Nan, was a maid in Alice Thornton's household in the early 1660s. We have not been able to identify her further.]

data.title: Elizabeth Wentworth (c.1614-1688)
data.bio: [Elizabeth Wentworth was the daughter of Godfrey and Anne Rhodes, born c.1614. She became the third wife of Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl Strafford, c.1632 and they had two children, Thomas and Margaret. She was also stepmother to Wentworth's children from his second wife, Arabella Holles. She died on 10 April 1688.]

data.title: Sir Thomas Wentworth (1593-1641)
data.bio: Thomas Wentworth, 1st Lord Raby, 1st Earl Strafford, was born on 13 April 1593 to William Wentworth, a Yorkshire landowner, and his wife Anne; he was their second and eldest surviving son. He was a childhood friend of Christopher Wandesford, both being educated by the Dean of Ripon. His first marriage to Margaret Clifford took place in 1611 and she died childless in August 1622. He married Arabella Holles in February 1625, and they had a son and two daughters. After her premature death on 6 October 1631, he married Elizabeth Rhodes in 1632 and had another son and daughter. In 1633 he was made Lord Deputy of Ireland and relocated to Dublin. He was recalled to England in 1639, was impeached and executed on 12 May 1641.

data.title: William Wentworth (1626-1695)
data.bio: [William Wentworth, 2nd Lord Raby, 2nd Earl Strafford, was born on 8 June 1626 to Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl Strafford, and his second wife, Arabella; he was their first child and only son. He married twice; first, Henrietta Maria Stanley and second, Henrietta de la Rochfoucauld. He died without issue on 16 October 1695, when the title Earl Strafford became extinct.]

data.title: Lady Philadelphia Wharton (died 1654)
data.bio: [This is probably Philadelphia Wharton, the daughter of Robert and Elizabeth Carey. She was a lady-in-waiting to Princess Elizabeth, Queen of Bohemia and married Sir Thomas Wharton of Aske Hall in on 11 April 1611. They had two sons. She died in 1654 and was buried at St Agatha’s church, Easby.]

data.title: Dr Ralph Widdrington (c.1614-1688)
data.bio: [Ralph Widdrington was the son of Lewis and Anne Widdrington of Cheesburn Grange, Northumberland, born in 1614/15. He attended Morpeth School and was then admitted to Christ's College, Cambridge in 1632. He was admitted to Gray's Inn in 1641, before being ordained and tutoring at Christ's, where he taught Thornton's younger brother, John Wandesford. He became Regius Professor of Greek in 1654 and was awarded a doctorate of Divinity in 1661. He died in Cambridge on 10 June 1688.]

data.title: Richard(?) Wilson (died 1669)
data.bio: [This is possibly Richard Wilson, rector of Holy Trinity, Chester, ordained in 1621. A royalist, he was absent in the early 1640s when he may have moved to St Michael's, Chester. He died in 1669.]

data.title: Dr Robert Wittie (1613-1684)
data.bio: Robert Wittie, the son of George and Anne Wittie of Beverley, was baptised at St Mary's, Beverley, on 14 November 1613. He studied medicine at King's College, Cambridge and returned to Yorkshire to practice medicine, first at Hull and then, from 1651 at the latest, at York. He treated Thornton and her family for various ailments. Wittie wrote at least two books; 'The Antimonial Cup' (1640), on emetics, and 'Scarborough Spaw' (1660), which extolled the healing virtues of spas. He married Mary Hall, who outlived him. In 1675, when his mother died, he was resident in the parish of St Martin's, Coney Street, York. On his retirement from active profession, he moved to London and was incorporated at the Royal College of Physicians on 30 September 1680. He died in October 1684.

data.title: Ezra Wollstone (n. d.)
data.bio: [Ezra Wollstone was a friend or acquaintance of Christopher Wandesford in Dublin in 1640. He is possibly the same gentleman of Newark that married Jane Halwell at St Peter’s, Farndon, Nottinghamshire on 15 February 1643; but we have not been able to identify him with any more certainty.]

Sir Christopher Wyvill (1614-1681)
data.bio: Sir Christopher Wyvill, 3rd Baronet of Constable Burton, was baptised on 6 December 1614, the eldest son and heir of Marmaduke and Isabel Wyvill. He married Ursula Darcy on 12 December 1636 and the couple had 12 children, six of whom died before them. He wrote an elegy for Alice Thornton's brother, George Wandesford, on his death in 1651. He was elected MP for Richmond in 1659 and returned to the Long Parliament in 1660. He was buried with his wife, who died in 1680, at St Mary’s, Masham on 8 February 1681.

data.title: Lady Ursula Wyvill (died 1680)
data.bio: [Lady Ursula Wyvill was the second child and eldest daughter of Conyers Darcy, 1st Earl Holderness and his wife, Grace. She married Sir Christopher Wyvill, 3rd Baronet of Constable Burton on 12 December 1636 and bore 12 children, six of whom survived to adulthood. She died in 1680.]

data.title: Sir John Yorke (c.1634-1663)
data.bio: Sir John Yorke was the son of John Yorke of Gouthwaite and his second wife, Catherine, born c.1634. He was educated at Queen's College, Oxford, matriculating in 1650. On 20 August 1651 he married Mary, daughter of Maulger and Anne Norton, and they had four children (three sons and a daughter). He was knighted by Charles II on his Restoration in 1660. He was elected MP for Richmond the following year, a position he held until his death on 1 April 1663, aged 29. He was buried at St Chad's, Middlesmoor.

data.title: Mary Yorke (1635-1675?)
data.bio: Mary Yorke, daughter and fourth child of Maulger and Anne Norton, was baptised at St Mary’s, Richmond on 12 July 1635; she was Alice Thornton's cousin. On 20 August 1651 she married John Yorke, a knight of Gouthwaite. They had four children, three sons and a daughter. She became a widow in 1663 and purchased the manor of Bewerley in 1675. We do not know when she died.
